sentence: The longer title for this use case is «Ethical and legal concerns of SyRi - the Dutch government's Risk Indication System (Systeem Risico Inventarisatie)».
The longer title for this use case is «Ethical and legal concerns of SyRi - the Dutch government's Risk Indication System (Systeem Risico Inventarisatie)».
30.1	Objective

As artificial intelligence is increasingly present in the development of governmental technology, and is replacing traditional decision trees or mind maps, policymakers, technology developers, and citizens face potential misunderstandings when relying on AI for predictions on the matters of social life.
The objective of this case study is to provide insight into the challenges of using automated decision support systems in the public sector.

As artificial intelligence is increasingly present in the development of governmental technology, and is replacing traditional decision trees or mind maps, policymakers, technology developers, and citizens face potential misunderstandings when relying on AI for predictions on the matters of social life.

As artificial intelligence is increasingly present in the development of governmental technology, and is replacing traditional decision trees or mind maps, policymakers, technology developers, and citizens face potential misunderstandings when relying on AI for predictions on the matters of social life.
The use case observed is the SyRi algorithm created and deployed in The Netherlands, whose lifespan of five years ended after a court ban in 2020 (Huisman, 2019).
The use case observed is the SyRi algorithm created and deployed in The Netherlands, whose lifespan of five years ended after a court ban in 2020 (Huisman, 2019).
Initiated by the Department of Social Affairs and Employment with the goal of preventing social fraud and abuse of welfare benefits, SyRi profiled citizens into ‘low’ and ‘high’ risk groups.
This case study reflects on the ethical and legal issues of automated decision-making in the public sector in general, and of SyRi in particular.
30.2	Technology
On the most general level, SyRi is a data-driven decision-making system.
Automation through AI enables the technical system to make conclusions and learn without explicit human involvement.
As it's fed with new data, Its ability to learn independently and change can advance, help or even fully replace human decision-making.

Considering that decision-making is one of the main tasks of the public sector, these emerging technologies carry great potential for better policymaking, more efficient interaction and delivery of services to citizens, or for support of the civil servants.
Automated decision-making systems rely on two key components: big data and algorithms.

Big data signifies the process of examining very large datasets in order to better understand the information, uncover patterns and correlations, and cannot be processed by humans without the software's processing power.

Big data signifies the process of examining very large datasets in order to better understand the information, uncover patterns and correlations, and cannot be processed by humans without the software's processing power.

Big data analytics is of particular relevance in the public sector as governments have access to vast amount of citizen data that can be structured, semi-structured or unstructured, as it gathered through formal channels (for e.g.

Big data analytics is of particular relevance in the public sector as governments have access to vast amount of citizen data that can be structured, semi-structured or unstructured, as it gathered through formal channels (for e.g.
In the case of SyRi data used included the following governmental data about the citizen:
•	work/ trade / employment data,
•	welfare benefits data,
•	data on historical compliance with laws,
•	debt data and
•	data on acquired fines,
•	property ownership information, and
•	health data.
The other key component, algorithms, are sets of instructions, often arranged in models, that process the data in order to abstract meaningful knowledge about it.

The definition used for the purpose of this use-case is the following: decision support systems are ‘procedures in which decisions are initially — partially or completely — delegated to another person or corporate entity, who then, in turn, use automatically executed decision-making models to perform an action’ (emphasis mine, AlgorithmWatch, 2019, p.9).

The definition used for the purpose of this use-case is the following: decision support systems are ‘procedures in which decisions are initially — partially or completely — delegated to another person or corporate entity, who then, in turn, use automatically executed decision-making models to perform an action’ (emphasis mine, AlgorithmWatch, 2019, p.9).

The definition used for the purpose of this use-case is the following: decision support systems are ‘procedures in which decisions are initially — partially or completely — delegated to another person or corporate entity, who then, in turn, use automatically executed decision-making models to perform an action’ (emphasis mine, AlgorithmWatch, 2019, p.9).
The first broad function can be seen as anticipation of future occurrences and includes issues such as crime prediction, welfare fraud prediction or abuse in families.
In the context of the public sector, so far, two stand out.

The second set of functions could be placed under the umbrella of detection, referring to tasks such as assessing fraudulent tax returns, mobility management tools, in water management systems or for re-evaluating demographic statistical data.
In this use case, the focus is on the algorithmic decision-making that anticipates and informs human decisions or even fully replaces them.
30.3	Context

The promise of versatile benefits has prompted governments, notably the United States, China, and the European Union member states to put AI development at the forefront of their agendas, including for the public sector digitalisation (Engstrom et al., 2020; Future of Life Institute, 2020; European Commission, 2020).
The public sector is eager to benefit from AI-based systems and big data repositories to improve their services, reduce costs, and keep up with the global technological innovation landscape.
The public sector is eager to benefit from AI-based systems and big data repositories to improve their services, reduce costs, and keep up with the global technological innovation landscape.
The public sector is eager to benefit from AI-based systems and big data repositories to improve their services, reduce costs, and keep up with the global technological innovation landscape.

The promise of versatile benefits has prompted governments, notably the United States, China, and the European Union member states to put AI development at the forefront of their agendas, including for the public sector digitalisation (Engstrom et al., 2020; Future of Life Institute, 2020; European Commission, 2020).

The promise of versatile benefits has prompted governments, notably the United States, China, and the European Union member states to put AI development at the forefront of their agendas, including for the public sector digitalisation (Engstrom et al., 2020; Future of Life Institute, 2020; European Commission, 2020).

Additionally, the European Union has stated its commitment to public sector AI as have numerous national AI strategies (European Commission, 2020; Misuraca & Van Noordt, 2020), including the Netherlands.
The SyRi algorithm’s main functions includes predictive analytics, as well as simulation and data visualization.
The key enablers are high quality data that the government possesses and the great ability of sharing the data and resources among ministries and local agencies.
The key enablers are high quality data that the government possesses and the great ability of sharing the data and resources among ministries and local agencies.
Once created, its expected impact was improved welfare services, less misuse of public funds and better inspection capabilities.

Particularly interesting context of SyRi as a public service algorithm is the court judgement that determined a 'black-box' algorithm unconstitutional, bringing the case into media spotlight nationally and internationally and determined.
This further implied that (1) invasion of privacy was unexpected for citizens, and (2) that they were unable to fight against its decisions.

After almost 6 years of an investigation, on 5 February 2020 The Hague District Court ruled that SyRi violated the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) by representing a ‘disproportionate invasion of the private life of citizens’ (Profiling and SyRI, 2015).
As a risk profiling system, SyRi linked and analyzed large amounts of data, of all citizens; both those identified as ‘high risk’ but also the ‘low risk’ groups.
As a risk profiling system, SyRi linked and analyzed large amounts of data, of all citizens; both those identified as ‘high risk’ but also the ‘low risk’ groups.
As a risk profiling system, SyRi linked and analyzed large amounts of data, of all citizens; both those identified as ‘high risk’ but also the ‘low risk’ groups.

As a risk profiling system, SyRi linked and analyzed large amounts of data, of all citizens; both those identified as ‘high risk’ but also the ‘low risk’ groups.
It further added that the existence of adequate legal privacy protection contributes to the trust of citizens and prevents a ‘chilling effect’ in citizen cooperation.
The decision (SyRi Judgement, 2020) concluded that Article 8 of the European Convention of Human Rights (ECHR) was breached by:
It further added that the existence of adequate legal privacy protection contributes to the trust of citizens and prevents a ‘chilling effect’ in citizen cooperation.
The use of machine learning algorithms for analysis and data correlation
Lack of citizen awareness of their data being processed
Separation of citizens into profiles with personal consequences through ‘risk reports’
The Court also found that SyRi poses an actual potential risk of discrimination of individuals due to its deployment in ‘problematic’, poorer neighborhoods (SyRi Judgement, 2020).
It emphasized the potential stigmatization based on socio-economic status, historical prejudice and biases that are also un-verifiable and hidden.

The Court judgement interestingly did not address the Article 22 of the European General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) in any extent, and instead relied on the Article 8 of the ECHR as a guiding principle.

The case of SyRi was a unique opportunity for an EU Member State to assess the scope and impact of Article 22 in relation to the use of automated decision-making in the context of public sector services.

The case of SyRi was a unique opportunity for an EU Member State to assess the scope and impact of Article 22 in relation to the use of automated decision-making in the context of public sector services.
Due to the brevity of this use case it is impossible to present the full analysis of the potential of GDPR to evaluate SyRi.
I will now briefly consider the impact of Article 22 only, as it addresses the data subject’s rights in relation to a fully automated decision-making system, such as SyRi.
I will now briefly consider the impact of Article 22 only, as it addresses the data subject’s rights in relation to a fully automated decision-making system, such as SyRi.

GDPR Article 22 (1) states that ‘the data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her’ (Article 22 GDPR).

Exclusions from this right apply in only three instances: a. the decision ‘is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller’; (2) ‘is authorized by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which also lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests’ or (3) ‘is based on the data subject's explicit consent’ (Article 22(2) GDPR).

Exclusions from this right apply in only three instances: a. the decision ‘is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller’; (2) ‘is authorized by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which also lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests’ or (3) ‘is based on the data subject's explicit consent’ (Article 22(2) GDPR).

GDPR Article 22 (1) states that ‘the data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her’ (Article 22 GDPR).

GDPR Article 22 (1) states that ‘the data subject shall have the right not to be subject to a decision based solely on automated processing, including profiling, which produces legal effects concerning him or her or similarly significantly affects him or her’ (Article 22 GDPR).

Exclusions from this right apply in only three instances: a. the decision ‘is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller’; (2) ‘is authorized by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which also lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests’ or (3) ‘is based on the data subject's explicit consent’ (Article 22(2) GDPR).

Exclusions from this right apply in only three instances: a. the decision ‘is necessary for entering into, or performance of, a contract between the data subject and a data controller’; (2) ‘is authorized by Union or Member State law to which the controller is subject and which also lays down suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests’ or (3) ‘is based on the data subject's explicit consent’ (Article 22(2) GDPR).

In the exclusions noted, the data controller is obliged to implement ‘suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, at least the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller, to express his or her point of view and to contest the decision’ (Article 22(3) GDPR).
Furthermore, the citizens had to right not to be subject to the processing.

In the exclusions noted, the data controller is obliged to implement ‘suitable measures to safeguard the data subject's rights and freedoms and legitimate interests, at least the right to obtain human intervention on the part of the controller, to express his or her point of view and to contest the decision’ (Article 22(3) GDPR).

According to the GDPR, SyRi does not comply as it did not fulfil the obligations from Article 22 (3) as citizens profiled were not given a chance to express their point of view, obtain explanation or defend their stance against the decision labelling them as potential ‘high’ risk in the Dutch welfare system.

According to the GDPR, SyRi does not comply as it did not fulfil the obligations from Article 22 (3) as citizens profiled were not given a chance to express their point of view, obtain explanation or defend their stance against the decision labelling them as potential ‘high’ risk in the Dutch welfare system.
Furthermore, the citizens had to right not to be subject to the processing.
Furthermore, the citizens had to right not to be subject to the processing.
Bearing in mind the legal concerns identified, in the next section I will present the ethical concerns detected in the selected literature on automated decision-making in the public sector.

When the public sector and automated decision-making systems interact, an obvious tension arises between the former resting on public accountability, responsibility, and public interest, and the later causing ‘significant concerns about the lack of due process, accountability, community engagement, and auditing’ (Whittaker et al.

When the public sector and automated decision-making systems interact, an obvious tension arises between the former resting on public accountability, responsibility, and public interest, and the later causing ‘significant concerns about the lack of due process, accountability, community engagement, and auditing’ (Whittaker et al.

With emerging technology such as artificial intelligence algorithms, whose main features are opacity and complexity, entrusting issues of public interest to uncertain and un-verifiable technological artifacts can erode trust and have far-reaching harmful consequences.

In the example of SyRi, Dutch citizens in Rotterdam took to the streets in protest of SyRi before the Court reached its judgement, but much after they themselves were marked a ‘high risk’ and stripped of social benefits by the Government (Huisman, 2019).
Algorithms are also treated as objects, man-made, and used by humans, that cause issues of privacy, manipulation, opacity, bias, and autonomy (Müller 2020).

Within the study of applied ethics of technology algorithms as SyRi are treated as technological artifacts since they carry particular risks on the issues of public policy, negotiation, and citizens' wellbeing.

Within the study of applied ethics of technology algorithms as SyRi are treated as technological artifacts since they carry particular risks on the issues of public policy, negotiation, and citizens' wellbeing.
In this context, ADMs have been researched for their impact on the economy, government, and workforce, but ethical considerations remain incomplete (Brynjolfsson & Mitchell, 2017).
In this context, ADMs have been researched for their impact on the economy, government, and workforce, but ethical considerations remain incomplete (Brynjolfsson & Mitchell, 2017).
The public sector perhaps carries the biggest weight because if its immense scope of impact on each citizen and the dire need for upkeeping citizen trust against dystopian scenarios.
The public sector perhaps carries the biggest weight because if its immense scope of impact on each citizen and the dire need for upkeeping citizen trust against dystopian scenarios.
Automated decision-making combines two axes of research: the ethics of data and the ethics of algorithms (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).
The first set of ethical concerns SyRi revealed is the one of privacy and personal data governance.
Profiling is enabled through data-merging, -linking and re-using datasets originally created for different purposes that can lead to the risks of so called ‘group privacy’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).

While citizens are not individually targeted, they are grouped into categories and ‘group privacy’ can lead to discrimination based on ethnicity, age, sex, economic status or be tied to the zip code as in the case of SyRi.

She further argues that the shift in this power balance disturbs fairness and equality, and leaves the profiled citizen as a dis-empowered constituent of a democracy, stripped away from its possibility to act in full knowledge and freedom (Hildebrandt, 2008).
Profiling is enabled through data-merging, -linking and re-using datasets originally created for different purposes that can lead to the risks of so called ‘group privacy’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).
Profiling is enabled through data-merging, -linking and re-using datasets originally created for different purposes that can lead to the risks of so called ‘group privacy’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).

While citizens are not individually targeted, they are grouped into categories and ‘group privacy’ can lead to discrimination based on ethnicity, age, sex, economic status or be tied to the zip code as in the case of SyRi.
The broad scope of government-owned data of citizens was used for profiling of citizens and classifying them into groups of ‘low’ and ‘high’ risk.
The broad scope of government-owned data of citizens was used for profiling of citizens and classifying them into groups of ‘low’ and ‘high’ risk.
The broad scope of government-owned data of citizens was used for profiling of citizens and classifying them into groups of ‘low’ and ‘high’ risk.

Profiling is enabled through data-merging, -linking and re-using datasets originally created for different purposes that can lead to the risks of so called ‘group privacy’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).
Profiling is enabled through data-merging, -linking and re-using datasets originally created for different purposes that can lead to the risks of so called ‘group privacy’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).

While citizens are not individually targeted, they are grouped into categories and ‘group privacy’ can lead to discrimination based on ethnicity, age, sex, economic status or be tied to the zip code as in the case of SyRi.

While the Court judgement did not explicitly detect discrimination, it warned of potential for it based on SyRi primarily operating in poorer neighborhoods, marking low-income citizens as expected ‘high’ risk or fraudulent welfare beneficiaries.
Profiling can even lead to serious harm to personal freedom and autonomy beyond privacy.
Profiling can even lead to serious harm to personal freedom and autonomy beyond privacy.

Hildebrandt (2008) argues that it affects the power relationship between the data controller (in this case the government) and the data subject (the citizen) as the citizen can be left without possibility to both demand and provide adequate interaction with its profiler.

Hildebrandt (2008) argues that it affects the power relationship between the data controller (in this case the government) and the data subject (the citizen) as the citizen can be left without possibility to both demand and provide adequate interaction with its profiler.

She further argues that the shift in this power balance disturbs fairness and equality, and leaves the profiled citizen as a dis-empowered constituent of a democracy, stripped away from its possibility to act in full knowledge and freedom (Hildebrandt, 2008).
A significant obstacle to less profiling and greater fairness, is the lack of transparency.

Various scholars have argued how machine learning algorithms as ‘black-boxes’ of complexity prevent understanding of the decisions and outcomes that can have significant impact on an individual’s wellbeing (Eubanks, 2018).

Like in the case of SyRi, an algorithm is put in place to determine whether a (usually) low-income family will be granted social benefits based on a myriad of statistical, personal and public data about the individual.
SyRi and similar fully independent, self-learning algorithms cannot give this explanation; neither to the citizen, nor the decision-makers nor to the engineers.
The transparency towards the citizens is low and, in turn, the citizen might lose his or her trust in to the social care system all together.
The system remains ‘opaque’ and unclear to the affected person (Danaher 2016, p. 245), as was noted by the Court in the SyRi decision.

It is important to note, however, that there is no consensus among ethicists of technology nor social scientists of technology about what information and to whom should be ‘opened’ from the algorithmic ‘black-box’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).

It is important to note, however, that there is no consensus among ethicists of technology nor social scientists of technology about what information and to whom should be ‘opened’ from the algorithmic ‘black-box’ (Floridi & Taddeo, 2016).
An important part of the public sector being able to cast decision is its democratic legitimacy as an instrumental value of a good society (Brey, 2018).

It has been argued that transparency about ADMs in public affairs affects the public perception of legitimacy and that a limited type of justified transparency is sufficient for perceived legitimacy (de Fine Licht and de Fine Licht, 2020) of the public sector.
Should SyRi or the minister from the Department of Social Affairs be held responsible and/or accountable for potential bias, discrimination, or profiling?
